name: Spring Boot Quickstart
description: Get started with Spring Boot and build production-ready Java applications quickly
fullDescription: This Spring Boot Quickstart course is designed for beginners who want to build Java-based backend applications with minimal configuration. You’ll learn the fundamentals of Spring Boot, understand how auto-configuration works, create REST APIs, connect to databases, and structure real-world applications. The course focuses on practical concepts with clear explanations, making it ideal for Java developers new to Spring Boot.

technicalContent.title: What is Spring Boot?
technicalContent.content: Spring Boot is a framework built on top of the Spring ecosystem that simplifies the development of Java applications. It eliminates boilerplate configuration by providing sensible defaults, embedded servers, and opinionated setup. This allows developers to focus more on business logic rather than infrastructure and configuration.

technicalContent.title: Why Use Spring Boot?
technicalContent.content: Spring Boot helps developers create stand-alone, production-ready applications quickly. It provides embedded servers like Tomcat, automatic dependency management, and seamless integration with databases and cloud platforms. These features make it ideal for microservices and modern backend development.

technicalContent.title: Creating a Spring Boot Application
technicalContent.content: A Spring Boot application starts with a main class annotated with @SpringBootApplication. This annotation enables auto-configuration, component scanning, and configuration support.

technicalContent.title: Understanding Auto Configuration
technicalContent.content: Auto-configuration is one of Spring Boot’s most powerful features. Based on the dependencies present in the project, Spring Boot automatically configures beans and application settings. This reduces manual configuration and speeds up development while still allowing customization when needed.

technicalContent.title: Spring Boot Project Structure
technicalContent.content: A typical Spring Boot project follows a layered structure with packages such as controller, service, repository, and model. This structure improves maintainability, readability, and scalability by separating concerns and responsibilities within the application.

technicalContent.title: Building a REST Controller
technicalContent.content: Spring Boot makes it easy to build RESTful APIs using annotations like @RestController and @GetMapping. Controllers handle HTTP requests and return responses in JSON or other formats.

technicalContent.title: Dependency Injection in Spring Boot
technicalContent.content: Dependency Injection (DI) allows Spring to manage object creation and dependencies automatically. By using annotations like @Component, @Service, and @Autowired, you can create loosely coupled and testable code.

technicalContent.title: Service Layer in Spring Boot
technicalContent.content: The service layer contains business logic and acts as an intermediary between controllers and repositories. It helps keep controllers lightweight and promotes clean architecture.

technicalContent.title: Database Integration with Spring Data JPA
technicalContent.content: Spring Data JPA simplifies database access by reducing boilerplate code. You can define repository interfaces, and Spring automatically provides implementations for common CRUD operations.

technicalContent.title: Application Properties and Configuration
technicalContent.content: Spring Boot uses application.properties or application.yml files to manage configuration such as server ports, database credentials, and logging levels. Externalized configuration makes applications easier to manage across different environments.

mcqQuestions.question: What is Spring Boot mainly used for?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Spring Boot is used to build stand-alone, production-ready Java applications with minimal configuration.

mcqQuestions.question: Which annotation is used to mark the main Spring Boot application class?
mcqQuestions.explanation: @SpringBootApplication enables auto-configuration, component scanning, and configuration support.

mcqQuestions.question: What is auto-configuration in Spring Boot?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Auto-configuration automatically configures beans and settings based on the dependencies present in the project.

mcqQuestions.question: Which annotation is used to create REST APIs in Spring Boot?
mcqQuestions.explanation: @RestController is used to create RESTful web services that return JSON responses.

mcqQuestions.question: Which embedded server is commonly used by Spring Boot?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Spring Boot uses Tomcat as the default embedded server, though others can be configured.

mcqQuestions.question: What does dependency injection help achieve?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Dependency injection promotes loose coupling and makes applications easier to test and maintain.

mcqQuestions.question: Which file is commonly used for configuration in Spring Boot?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Spring Boot uses application.properties or application.yml for configuration.

mcqQuestions.question: What is the role of the service layer?
mcqQuestions.explanation: The service layer contains business logic and keeps controllers lightweight.

mcqQuestions.question: Which Spring Boot module simplifies database operations?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Spring Data JPA reduces boilerplate code for database access and CRUD operations.

mcqQuestions.question: What is a key advantage of Spring Boot?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Spring Boot speeds up development by providing defaults, auto-configuration, and embedded servers.
